captions.text: I think it’s one of the most important spots in the world...perhaps in Europe it’s Tre Cima
It’s the equivalent to Yosemite in the U.S.A. it is sort of a mandatory place to see that has been around forever
We were really looking forward coming to Tre Cima, this is a
worldwide reference route and we are really excited to give it a try!
It’s a good day
I finally had a very good night
Pous awakenings’ are awesome! (Iker in the background, joking: Very good)
No, we really hate getting up early... it’s one of
of the things we don’t really manage very good. If we have to we’ll do it, but we’re not really up to it.
Panaroma is not an easy route it goes through a lot of traverses...and it has two parts:
The first part, the first 200 meters its sort of a very vertical
and technical climbing, with very bad fasteners
It’s what we call a “marron“, really dangerous pitches, 30 to 35 meters
long, fasteners pushed into rotten rock... and if you fall, the secure points may blow... so you go climbing
quite scared and that makes you tensioned
and that leads in that when we get to the 6th pitch, the first 8a+, is very technically demanding
we already have already supported a lot of tension and it’s difficult to cope with it
The menu...pasta! Pasta with peppers, onion,
it’s gonna be impressive!
We’ll end up as “chancho“
It’s a very futuristic route... because
it’s a route that goes through a huge boulder, one the biggest and more important in the world
and so it has little to do with the rest of routes
What’s up? Hey Alex You’re very thin! Look to the weather you carry with you!
Basque guys arrive and bad weather comes with them, ah?! Let’s get inside, it’s pouring down!
Different, eh? For being a Big Wall different cause they’re usually very technical and
It’s very different
It’s very physical and if you fall you might end up....
And then we get to the next part, what we could call the  big “ceiling“ of the route
and there. there is when the complications really begin... you have to move 65 meters horizontally to the right in continuous traverse
and there is a huge distance in between the fastener points, and in case of falling, those are huge
flys where you would get completely suspended in the air...
We could say it’s a very sort of “gorilla climbing“, very physically demanding
very different, it’s an incredible climb
it is said by a lot of people that it’s the biggest ceiling in the world
but you have to see it! You have to see that wall!
This is an absolutely unique formation all around the world
and that is way is something I just could not resist.
In my opinion Panaroma is the most impressive route that I have completed because
I’ve never seen such a unique formation as The Tre Cime
A route like Panaroma needs of all your strength to be
achieved and can only be completed by the best climbers in the world

comments.text:
ahahaha..funny..but it's a route you better not fall cause the pitons are 
not "fix" or "spit" ...the pitons are knocked in in very small slots or 
fissure and are not solid at all..it's also a multi pitch 500 metres, 8c 
and overhanging route in high mountain at 2000 metres on the sea level and 
requires 3 o 4 hours approaching..
comments.author: albyuke

comments.text:
That's actually not how it works. Those "little things in the wall" are 
protection devices and you don't leave them in the wall and jump off. They 
are collected by the follower when the lead climber reaches the ends of a 
pitch and goes on belay. To get down you will rappel back down from a top 
anchor.

comments.text:
@MrSTR8eigh7 You only get one reserve. Once you've deployed it. You no 
longer have a "reserve" your primary is cut away and lands several minutes 
later. Your reserve becomes your primary. It's just the feeling that sets 
in that you don't have anything else to go to. That's it. Sounds pretty cut 
and dry, but the feeling of riding down without further back up gets 
creepier the longer your thoughts dwell on it. lol
comments.author: briansmobile1
